So the other day two very similar but with opposing perspectives threads came out. Both of the seperate discussions were about the lore shift in Volibear, with the one here on SA&S being more optimistic about Voli's future LU while the one over at ~~GA~~ GD was much less so.

Checking most recently it seems that based on upvotes alone the optimistic people are the minority with half the number of votes (70 to 30). So, is the new direction a bad shift in the Storm Bear's character? To steal from another commenter: is this the new "Mah Viktor is not a villian!" ?

Edit: As someone who's on the fence but prefers the new approach only because I never really cared for his old lore, this debate from players has me very curious.
What's GA?
General Discussions was the intended abbreviation, stupid me hit the wrong key.

Meh some people are going to piss regardless of what happens to the lore honestly. It seems to be me all the haters manage to gather in GD to stroke their hate boner and judging the quality of their arguement they usually brings, it's fairly easily debunked.

Honestly I find these people rather amusing since half of the time their arguement can catergorize as two things, personal taste and ignorance. 

Quite frankly I've been following the lore long enough to remeber what the old lore is like. If they were honest with themselves, they would realize that the old lore has little to no substance to it. It's likely they had gotten attach to alot fanon or personal headcanon in their head that were squash by Riot new direction. This freakout is going occur time and time again after each LU, especially with the more ethtablish region such as Noxus, Ionia and Demacia.

Regardless I really don't think Riot should listen to these people, as often then not they are rather self absorbed about their own belief. It's like argueing with comic book fan who is extremely stuck on to the old canon everytime a major retcon occurs. It's the pain of dealing with retcons, people get attach to old things that they are blinded with reality.  

As for how Voli direction wise, I say I like it better than another generic goody goody leader who was allied with ashe. A demi god thunder bear is more intresting than a bear war chief, I say but that's not every cup of tea, which is fine.

Im just disappointed there weren't many from here in SA&S to tell the others that, because you and I are on the exact same page.

I did call them for what they were- cynical d-bags and that seemed to gather positive votes.

I'm not particularly intrested in going out and witch hunting haters unfortunately. I have really given up on these people hence why took a break from here for a few month. I'm quite frankly tires of discussing the merit of the lore because it always ends overly written version of riot lore sucks because it doesn't satisfy my personal taste regarding stories therefore it's crap. Which at that point, how are you going respond that?  

Sorry ramble lol. I much prefer to talk about some tiny lore tibit and hints I found the lore. Such as the theory of  Valoran and southern continent use to be one major continent but was seperate due two world rune colliding (in ryzes lore) that seperated the continets. But I find not alot of people are interesting in theorycrafting these days.
Reading through the lore I'm kinda curious what's league definition of god, demgods are. Why is Ornn seen as a demigod when he's feats cold fully made hin define as a god.
Probably because actual gods are so powerful that even Ornn doesn't compare to them anymore.
I suppose, but that makes me wonder what is the god of runeterra is like is Ornn is just a demi god. I know runeterra does havea system wherebu belief makes them more powerful.

Nagakaborous.
I think one factor that all demi-gods in Runeterra lack is the Omnipresence of Nagakaborous.
Sure you only see her if you're being tested, but it doesn't mean she moved towards you, she was always there, you're just seeing her now - as she is the deity of the most permanent thing ever in the known Universe (Valoran or our own): change.

All the other gods are tethered to a physical form or area. The Aspects only connect to their Avatars at Mt. Targon. The Freljord deities... are well in Freljord. The Ascended are quiet powerful but they got locked away/cryostasis. Even Bard has a physical form

The only exception would be Kindred: 1) because Death is an absolute, it doesn't need a god and thus they aren't gods, but rather something akin to us wanting to face death - personified 2) while having a physical form it seems to be highly subjective and is omnipresent as well: meaning a Demacian and Noxian both die by the Wolf in their respective side of Valoran at the same time. They both catch a glimpse of the Wolf  but he looks entirely different for the former and the latter.

and A'Sol... cause he's from the Universe and was only forcefully tethered to Valoran.

Something that confused me and is making me struggle to better understand this is that this entire thing ties in the Volibear rework and re-imagines a lot of the 2011 (?) Freljord rework.

I think the Freljord is one of (if not the most) interesting regions in League because it has an ongoing Civil War. There's Avarosa, Frost Guard, and Winter's Claw. Champions are part of different factions. Volibears old lore says he was an Ursine chieftain who joined the Winter's Claw for reasons. Now it seems Volibear is a Demigod who aligned himself with the Winter's Claw tribe? At least, my understanding of the Ursine/Volibear were part of Sejuani's faction.

This made this line read pretty weird:

> We could only ever stand a chance against the Winter’s Claw. If the Ursine struck first, our defense would be terrifyingly short. That hideous legion of half-bear abominations would overwhelm us.

Because if you read it knowing the old lore, you'd be wondering why they'd only stand a chance against the Winter's Claw when the Ursine are considered _part of the_ Winter's Claw. I was wondering if they renamed the Winter's Claw as the Ursine Faction and Sejuani was getting a different tribe name at first. Now it seems there's some kind of half-bear-man alliance with a human tribe. It's not a bad idea. It's cool actually. I just think the story didn't do enough to emphasize they're separate but coordinated armies.

Other than that, the story follows typical Riot Narrative patterns of '_everyone that is pretty much everyone of no consequence going to die_'-sort of ending except this implies the people either fought to the death or somehow fought to survive against impossible odds. I think the universe building suffers a lot from this - there's simply just never any secondary characters of any consequence and those that are introduced (like MF's first mate Rafen) are shown to be incompetent.

Voli was only switch side during the frejord event with little reason as to why. His orginal lore had him allied with ashe, so his lore was in limbo until recently.

Also the color story is meant to focus on Ornn itself, the ursine and voli are to act as secondary point which will be further expanded upon once Voli lore comes out.

Also color story are meant to focus ingame champion. Ornn color story isn't meant to be about kriek the blind legless men, but about Ornn instead.

> Also color story are meant to focus ingame champion. Ornn color story isn't meant to be about kriek the blind legless men, but about Ornn instead.

And this is a huge problem in League's universe where any secondary character isn't worth two shits.

They are secondary characters for reason, and not suppose to out shine the champions. Champions aren't just meant to be protagonist but also meant to the very important figures with the league universe...

Beside Rafen snuvked in and blew up Gankplank ship while Mf was distracting everyone. Just because he was potray as weaker in the shadow and fortune story doesn't mean he is actually weak.

Rafen serves as fluff jobber for MF so she can show off how much more she knows than Rafen. 

Secondary characters may not be the most important but in the vast, VAST majority of League lore they're expendable red shirts that try to make us feel the 'stakes are raise, hehehe!' just because a few of these one-off names die or something.

It's simply not interesting.

But these character are design that way. If they outshine the champion, then why don't they make them the champion instead? 

I don't see why it's boring? A champion is meant to be the important character in a story, I don't see why they shouldn't get the main spotlight in a story. Beside their it's not as if a champion can't be a secondary character in a story, like illaoi in shadow and fortune.

> But these character are design that way. If they outshine the champion, then why don't they make them the champion instead?

The characters are designed to be fluff jobbers to champions. Riot Narrative is really poor at developing a universe that exists outside of a champion's immediate sphere. Nothing exists beyond the champions. That makes it extremely limiting and boring especially when you consider almost all other secondary characters die.

You can't build a universe on the back of just demi-gods. You need mortals that are interesting, compelling, and alive (looking at you Quintella) to make the League universe feel, well, LIKE A UNIVERSE.

It's boring because a lot of these champions don't have interesting story arcs. The good chunk of them are now god-like beings beyond our mortal understanding (Bard, Kalista, Ornn) but it's precisely because they're beyond mortal understanding that they're boring characters.

Damn I did not know Caitlyn, Gankplank, twisted fate, Vi, Jayce, Garen, are suddenly demi god and immortals. Gee wiz how could I possible miss that. 

Also I don't see being champion focus at this stage is some how not being a universe. It seems to me that this is issue of your subjective feeling about not being in a universe. Well I disagree with your feeling and I think the lore is currently very satisfying, and able to visualize the places describe.

Hey someone who tells the other gods to fuck off and stop messing with humans. I'm all for that. 

But overall, I felt the lost tales of Ornn was better. This background basically just told the same stories but with a more generic and cliched method of imparting the information. "No mortals could comprehend"? Bear dude wanted armor. Ram dude said no. It doesn't really take much to comprehend that. Which is usually the case with those sort of statements. Unless your character is entirely alien to the point they no longer follow logic or emotional responses then people will be able to comprehend it just fine.

I think of it this way, no one actually saw the start of the battle. Some of the Lost Tales are myths and a lot of it seems like the storytellers of each generation had to fill in the blanks, like the story of how the Freljord had its first snow but hasn't stopped snowing since. 

The storyteller for that particular story probably just filled in what they believed started the fight with what they know about Volibear.

Sure, that's a good headcanon and probably what the writer actually meant. But that's not what beyond mortal comprehension means. That's "for reasons no one knows" or to be fancier "for reasons lost to time."

Given that Orrn and Volibear hate each other before the destruction of the Hearthblood, we have no idea why Volibear decided to start that. Do we need to? Do we need to know the root cause of why two demigods hate each other, when it might not even actually make sense to us? That could become a long story in itself. Those legends may get told at some point, but they aren't necessarily important.

No we don't.  But I'm not saying we need every detail.  My point is there is a difference between "beyond comprehension" and "we just don't know yet."

The first is directly stating that humans cannot grasp what their motivations are.  They are alien, unknowable, their actions may as well be random for all we can figure out.

But that is not what the lores have shown us.  They seem to have pretty standard reasons for why they do things.  They hate each other.  That's an emotional response humans can very well comprehend.  I daresay all of us have felt angry enough to lash out before.  

My point, words have meanings.  Use them correctly, especially if you're a writer.

Don't forget to read the color text. The Bio is meant to be a summary of the character. FWIW, I enjoyed writing Lost Tales more. Bios are a lot harder.

I did, still liked Lost Tales more, had a nice vibe to it that seemed to get the oral traditions of mythologies a lot better than some of Riot's other attempts (the Targon lore for example).

Mostly, my problem comes from disliking the scope that you guys have decided to take the story in general, and it is just pretty blatantly on display in the Ornn lore.  Humans are in trouble, they're against some otherworldly force, they can't do jack about it.  Then a god shows up to solve their problems for them because their opponent is literally beyond their scope to deal with.  And it works in this story, because the focus is on introducing Ornn, nor the tale of the unnamed narrator and their tribe.  They are just the framing device for Ornn.

But, as a whole, I don't really care about the troubles between Ornn and Volibear.  I'm way more interested in which of the queens gets the crown.  But the queens don't matter once gods are on the playing field.  What is Ashe going to do now that Volibear is working for her enemy?  Get some god to do her work for her?  That's not compelling.  Why does it matter if Ashe is a good queen or not when Volibear or Anivia or Ornn could turn everything she does to rubble and make the world as they want it?  She's insignificant.

Same thing happened in Shurima.  Xerath is trying to kill Sivir.  Xerath can turn rocks into a gas in a second.  There is nothing that Sivir can do against Xerath.  So, thankfully she has Nasus to go do the fighting for her.  That's pretty lame.

Or Targon.  We have Pantheon, Pantheon's opponent is a star creating dragon from space.  Pantheon is a guy with a spear.  Admittedly, a guy with a spear that's supposed to be possessed by an alien parasite.  But still his body can be killed like any other.  So what does he do against a star dragon?  Probably something overtly magical, or that fight ends in 1/2 a second.  But, this is Pantheon.  He's the warrior guy.  He's the soldier.  Who thought it was a good idea to tie him to the magic god shenanigans?
